articles.title: 404: Page not found
articles.contents:
Sorry, something messed up. Please click here to go back to the homepage.
If you clicked on something and expected something different than this 404 page, please DM me on Twitter and let me know what happened.

articles.title: Archive
articles.contents:
Here is an archive of R cheatsheets and presentations I made when I was a postbacc at the University of Michigan. The presentations will download as a .pptx file.
Most of the cheatsheets are old and were made when I didn’t know R as well as I do now, but I still like them. I might try to make updated versions in the future.
Cheatsheet
Date Created
The Basics of Data Wrangling
September 17, 2019
A Very Short Review of ggplot2
April 8, 2019
TaDLab’s Guide to Making Pretty RMarkdown Documents
March 19, 2019
Learning R
November 7, 2018
Presentation
Date Created
How to Apply to Graduate School in Psychology
February 12, 2020
Clinical Interviewing with the SCID-5
October 16, 2019
Introduction to Statistics, R, and RStudio
October 2, 2019

            About Me
            I am a graduate student in the Clinical Psychology Program at The Ohio State University. My research interests include emotion regulation and facial affective behavior. I am a member of the Children and Parents Lab under Dr. Sarah Schoppe-Sullivan.
            
            
            Education
            Doctorate of Philosophy in Psychology, 2020 - Present
            
            The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH
            
            Bachelors of Arts in Psychology, 2014 - 2018
            
            Smith College, Northampton, MA

articles.contents:
Contents
Introduction
Symbols
Diagrams

Regression
Intercept only
Simple linear regression
Simple linear regresion with mean-centered x
Multiple linear regression
Interaction / Moderation

Nested data
Fixed effects model
Random effects ANOVA
Random intercept regression model
Means as outcomes
Intercepts as outcomes


Introduction
Symbols
Symbol
Mean
Symbol
Meaning


\(\beta_{0}\)
Intercept
\(\sigma\)
Variance


\(\beta_{1}\)
Slope
\(\sigma^2\)
Standard deviation


\(\epsilon_{i}\)
Error
\(x_{1}\)
Sample statistic


\(\hat{y}\)
Estimate
\(x'_{1}\)
Mean-centered sample statistic


\(\bar{y}\)
Average
\(\mu\)
Population parameter


\(N\)
Sample size
\(N \sim (0,1)\)
Population distribution


Symbol
Meaning
\(i\)
Individual or case (Level-1)
\(j\)
Group or cluster (where \(j\) = 1, …, \(J\); Level-2)
\(\gamma_00\)
Fixed intercept and the grand mean, i.e., the overall average value of \(\bar{y}\)
\(\upsilon_{0j}\)
Between-group variability: the deviation of group \(j\) from the overall average \(\gamma_00\).
\(\epsilon_{ij}\)
Within-group variability: the case residual (within-group).
\(\tau_{00}\)
Variance of the Level-2 random intercepts
\(\sigma^2\)
Variance of the Level-1 random intercepts
\(\beta_{0j}\)
Random intercept
\(\beta_{1j}\)
Random slope
Diagrams
When you make diagrams, put them here!
Regression
Independent variables: \(x_1\), \(x_2\), \(x_3\), …
Dependent variable: \(Y\)
Intercept only
\[
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{i}} = \beta_{0} + \epsilon_{i}
\]


Show code
m1 <- lm(mpg ~ 1, mtcars)
tab_model(m1, 
          show.ci = FALSE, show.se = TRUE, show.stat = TRUE,
          string.intercept = "Intercept", string.se = "SE", string.stat = "t",
          dv.labels = "Intercept Only")

 


Intercept Only


Predictors


Estimates

t


p


Intercept

18.86

Observations

R2 / R2 adjusted


0.000 / 0.000


Simple linear regression
\[
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{i}} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}x_{i} + \epsilon_{i}
\]


Show code
m2 <- lm(mpg ~ hp, mtcars)
tab_model(m2,           
          show.ci = FALSE, show.se = TRUE, show.stat = TRUE,
          string.intercept = "Intercept", string.se = "SE", string.stat = "t",
          dv.labels = "Simple linear regression")

 


Simple linear regression

Simple linear regresion with mean-centered x
\[
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{i}} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}x'_{i} + \epsilon_{i}
\]


Show code
mtcars$hp_c <- scale(mtcars$hp, center=TRUE, scale=FALSE) 
m3 <- lm(mpg ~ hp_c, mtcars)
tab_model(m3,           
          show.ci = FALSE, show.se = TRUE, show.stat = TRUE,
          string.intercept = "Intercept", string.se = "SE", string.stat = "t",
          dv.labels = "Simple linear regression with mean-centered x")

Multiple linear regression
\[
\LARGE {\operatorname{Y_{i}} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}x_1{i} + \beta_{2}x_2{i} + \epsilon_{i}}
\]


Show code
m4 <- lm(mpg ~ hp + qsec, mtcars)
tab_model(m4, 
          show.ci = FALSE, show.se = TRUE, show.stat = TRUE,
          string.intercept = "Intercept", string.se = "SE", string.stat = "t",
          dv.labels = "Multiple linear regression")

 


Multiple linear regression

Interaction / Moderation
\[
\LARGE \hat{\operatorname{Y}} = \hat{\beta}_{0} + \hat{\beta}_{1}x_1 + \hat{\beta}_{2}x_2 + \hat{\beta}_{3}x_1x_2
\]
Also can be written as:
\[
\LARGE \hat{\operatorname{Y}} = \hat{\beta}_{0} + \hat{\beta}_{1}x_1 + (\hat{\beta}_{2} + \hat{\beta}_{3}x_1)x_2 + \epsilon_{i}
\]


Show code
m5 <- lm(mpg ~ hp + qsec + hp:qsec, mtcars)
tab_model(m5, 
          show.ci = FALSE, show.se = TRUE, show.stat = TRUE,
          string.intercept = "Intercept", string.se = "SE", string.stat = "t", 
          dv.labels = "Moderated regression")

 


Moderated regression


Predictors

8.52

The effect of one predictor depends on the level of the other predictor, i.e., the effect of one predictor is moderated by the level of the other predictor.
\(x_1\) is the focal predictor and \(x_2\) is the moderating variable.
Nested data
Fixed effects model
\[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{i}} = {\beta}_{1}x_{1i} + {\beta}_{2}x_{2i} + ... + {\beta}_{p}x_{pi} + \epsilon_{i}
\] \[
\LARGE \epsilon_{i} \sim_{iid} N(0, \sigma^2)
\]


Show code
# m6 <- ???
# idk how to do this in R...

Random effects ANOVA
Level-1: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{ij}} = \beta_{0j} + \epsilon_{ij}
\] \[
\LARGE \epsilon_{i} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Level-2: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{\beta_{0j}} = \gamma_{00} + \upsilon_{0j}
\] \[
\LARGE \upsilon_{0j} \sim_{iid} N(0, \tau_{00})
\]
Reduced: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{ij}} = \gamma_{00} + \upsilon_{0j} + \epsilon_{ij}
\]


Show code
data(sleepstudy)
m7 <- lme4::lmer(Reaction ~ 1 + (1|Subject), sleepstudy)
tab_model(m7,           
          show.ci = FALSE, show.se = TRUE, show.stat = TRUE,
          string.intercept = "Intercept", string.se = "SE", string.stat = "t", 
          dv.labels = "Random effects ANOVA")

 


Random effects ANOVA


Predictors


Estimates


SE


t


p


Intercept


298.51


9.05


32.98


<0.001


Random Effects


σ2

1958.87


τ00Subject

1278.34


ICC


0.39


N Subject

18


Observations


180


Marginal R2 / Conditional R2

0.000 / 0.395


Also known as a one-way random effects model.
The Level-1 equation is a model for within-group differences, whereas the Level-2 equation is a model for between-group differences.
The fixed effects of the model are constant for all cases in the population and do not carry \(i\) or \(j\) subscripts. The Greek symbol gamma (\(\gamma\)) denotes these effects.
The random effects of the model vary across Level-1 and Level-2 units. Effects that vary across Level-2 units are denoted by \(u\); effects that vary across Level-1 units are denoted by \(\epsilon\).
Random intercept regression model
Level-1: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{ij}} = \beta_{0j} + \beta_{1j}x_{ij} + \epsilon_{ij}
\] \[
\LARGE \epsilon_{i} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Level-2: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{\beta_{0j}} = \gamma_{00} + \upsilon_{0j}
\] \[
\LARGE \operatorname{\beta_{1j}} = \gamma_{10}
\] \[
\LARGE \upsilon_{0j} \sim_{iid} N(0, \tau_{00})
\]
Reduced: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{ij}} = \gamma_{00} + \gamma_{10}x_{ij} + \upsilon_{0j} + \epsilon_{ij}
\]


Show code
#m8 <- ??

\(x_{ij}\) is a Level-1 predictor because it varies between group \(j\) and case \(i\). This model has four parameters:
A fixed intercept, \(\gamma_{00}\)
A fixed effect of \(x_{ij}\), \(\gamma_{10}\)
Residual variance of the Level-2 random intercepts, \(\tau_{00}\)
Residual variance at Level-1, \(\sigma^2\)
The fixed effects are \(\gamma_{00}\) and \(\gamma_{10}\). The random effect is \(\tau_{00}\). The covariance parameters are \(\tau_{00}\) and \(\sigma^2\).
Means as outcomes
Level-1: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{ij}} = \beta_{0j} + \epsilon_{ij}
\] \[
\LARGE \epsilon_{i} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Level-2: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{\beta_{0j}} = \gamma_{00} + \gamma_{01}w_{j} + \upsilon_{0j}
\] \[
\LARGE \upsilon_{0j} \sim_{iid} N(0, \tau_{00})
\]
Reduced: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{ij}} = \gamma_{00} + \gamma_{01}w_{j} + \upsilon_{0j} + \epsilon_{ij}
\]
Here, we incorporate Level-2 predictors to the random effects ANOVA model.
In a means as outcomes model, the means \(\beta_{0j}\) are predicted with at least one Level-2 variable, \(w\). Level-2 variables are literally cluster means, and the model regresses \(\beta_{0j}\) onto these means.
The fixed effects are \(\gamma_{00}\) and \(\gamma_{01}\). The random effect is \(\tau_{00}\). The covariance parameters are \(\tau_{00}\) and \(\sigma^2\).
Intercepts as outcomes
Level-1: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{ij}} = \beta_{0j} + \beta_{1j}x_{ij} + \epsilon_{ij}
\] \[
\LARGE \epsilon_{i} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Level-2: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{\beta_{0j}} = \gamma_{00} + \gamma_{01}w_{j} + \upsilon_{0j}
\] \[
\LARGE \operatorname{\beta_{1j}} = \gamma_{10}
\] \[
\LARGE \upsilon_{0j} \sim_{iid} N(0, \tau_{00})
\]
Reduced: \[ 
\LARGE \operatorname{Y_{ij}} = \gamma_{00} + \gamma_{01}w_{j} + \gamma_{10}x_{ij} + \upsilon_{0j} + \epsilon_{ij}
\]
Here, we incorporate Level-2 predictors to the random intercepts regression model. The random intercepts \(\beta_{0j}\) are predictor with at least one Level-2 variable \(w\).
The fixed effects are \(\gamma_{00}\) and \(\gamma_{10}\). The random effect is \(\tau_{00}\). The covariance parameters are \(\tau_{00}\) and \(\sigma^2\).

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
As an undergraduate at Smith College, I was a member of Dr. Nnamdi Pole’s lab. I completed my senior thesis on facial expressivity, emotional coherence, and PTSD in a psychotherapy case study.
After graduating, I joined Dr. Christoper Monk’s lab as a postbacc lab manager and coordinated study efforts with the Study of Adolescent Neural Development (SAND), a substudy of the Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study. I am currently writing a paper on ventral striatum connectivity and reward processing in the SAND sample; we hope to submit it to Brain Research soon.
I joined The Ohio State University’s clinical psychology program in Fall 2020. I completed my firstyear project on automated facial expression coding in mother-daughter dyads with Nathaniel Haines.
Broadly speaking, I am interested in affective science and emotion regulation in clinical populations. I am happiest when working with big datasets that need carpentry and visualization. Please contact me via email or Twitter if you are interested in collaboration.
